Pact is one of four implementers of Pamoja Tuwalee /PT, a five-year project that aims to provide coordinated and sustainable care for OVC and households infected and affected by HIV in the Lake, Southern, and Southern Highlands Zones, covering ten regions of Tanzania. The objectives of the project are to: increase local ownership and capacity to support OVC to access community based care and support; strengthen the capacity of local government authorities and civil society to provide quality services to OVC and their households; and replicate effective multi-sectoral coordination structures that include the private sector at all levels. The project is aligned with the OVC National Costed Action Plan, PEPFAR OVC programming guidance, and PEPFAR/T’s goal of scaling-up services to reduce morbidity and mortality and improve the lives of Tanzanians affected by HIV, and the Global Health Initiative strategy of increasing access to quality maternal, child, and reproductive health services.
Pact/PT uses the WORTH economic strengthening model approach, a savings-led finance program, to enhance vulnerable households’ capacity to provide care and support to their families sustainably. The WORTH platform also allows for the integration of critical social and health services, such as child protection and GBV. Economically empowered OVC households are then graduated from the WORTH model, promoting longer-term impact after program ends.
Pact/PT will continue to collect and utilize program data as identified in the M&E plan. The recent PT mid-term performance evaluation findings will be used to improve data analysis and service delivery. Pact/PT will continue to contribute to the evidence base by documenting best practices and child health integration models in the three zones. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.8: Orphans and Vulnerable Children. Activities are aimed at improving the lives of orphans and other vulnerable children (OVC) affected by HIV/AIDS, and doing so in a measurable way. objectives
